text: Alright, the next talk is by Bert Burgers towards autonomous urban digital twins.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is a 20 minute video.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For the next 20 minutes, I will talk about transport policy planning and how active inference could be applied through digital twins.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Urban planning is a very broad field encompassing everything that occurs in urban regions, from the design and operation of infrastructure to social programs.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: To scope this, I will focus on the transport system, giving a rough sketch of what active inference may entail for this domain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Modeling the transport system relies on operationalizing decision making.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Many individual choices lead to busy roads.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Therefore, the main storyline focuses on the difference between active and passive decision-making.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The presentation is structured in three parts.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: First is the context, giving an outline of urban digital twins.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I will focus on livability as it is an objective of transport policy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Next, I will present some domain-specific building blocks, which are then combined in the final part.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Finally, I hypothesize that renormalizing generative models can be used as transport models.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: concluding that active inference-based modeling might require a new perspective on transport planning.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: First, I will give some context in order to frame how active inference, transport planning and digital trends come together.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The field of transport planning is moving towards the development of digital twins.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: These twins enable quick calculation of effects given an intervention.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Rather than performing a comprehensive study per project, which can take months, a digital twin can be reused many times.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: An example application would be the construction of a new neighborhood.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What are the effects on congestion, air quality and inundation risk?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There are roughly five levels.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The first introduces a compelling visual interface, often involving a 3D representation of the real urban region.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Next is the addition of information on top of the visualization.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and the geographic data works.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The third step not only maps data, but incorporates different physics-based models.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Hence, it is called predictive.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Transport models are one example, others are airflow or water simulations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: High-performance computing speeds up the scope of parameters which can be tested.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The fourth level builds on top of the predictive models by adding an interpretive layer.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The added value is scenario-based planning, where a range of outcomes is calculated for a hypothetical intervention.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Instead of configuring parameters exactly, you could propose a preferred outcome to the computer, and that would only simulate what is necessary, as it understands relations between models.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The last level introduces autonomy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Not only are physics-based models configured intelligently, as in step 4, but the twin actively goes out to construct its niche.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: transport policy evaluation is going through somewhat of a change.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In decades before, the development of transport models allowed the paradigm of predict and provide.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We could forecast traffic flows and accordingly invest in infrastructure to prevent congestion.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: More recently, the field has acknowledged that models trained on past data are inherently flawed in predicting in certain futures.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As such, it is moving towards scenario-based planning, sometimes described as decide and provide.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Along with this change comes a reflection on the philosophical context.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For simplicity, I rely on two frameworks.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The first is utilitarianism.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It relies on the assumption of rational choice, enabling the quantification of benefits and costs in terms of utility and disutility.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Between every origin and destination,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There are several alternative routes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Each has attributes such as the distance traveled and the cost.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Combined with preferences, we get generalized travel cost.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The rational choice assumption enables fungibility.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This allows us to take the ratio of estimated better parameters and utility functions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: These ratios can then be used to calculate, for example, the monetary value of travel time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In practice, we always use monetary value as the final measure so that we can compare the cost of implementation against the benefits experienced.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Finally, utilitarianism leads to aggregate increases in welfare at the ignorance of the distribution.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Not only this is applied to wealth, but accessibility too.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Take for example the discrepancy in infrastructure spending between core cities and the periphery.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: To address these concerns, contemporary policy evaluation attempts to move away from utilitarianism.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Instead of attempting to relate our preferences to monetary value, we leave them separate.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Not only do we reject the fungibility of indicators, but we also consider many more than before.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Shown in this wheel, spanning from living environment, accessibility, health and safety.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Finally, the distribution of costs and benefits is explicitly considered, and much work is now spent on reworking existing modelling frameworks to make these distributions explicit.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There are three main objectives in planning infrastructure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Accessibility, safety and livability.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Capturing livability is much more difficult than accessibility and safety.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Livability is generally defined as the fit in an ecological relationship between resident and the living environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: With regard to the spatio-temporal scale of this relationship, livability is local and sustainability is global.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For practical reasons, fit is operationalized through valuation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The more an environment can satisfy one's preferences, the greater the fit.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Theoretically, it has been long known that fit could also be operationalized as a continuous transactional process.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: However, little progress has been made.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this is where active inference comes in.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: These two approaches to livability are best defined by contrasting them to each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the one hand, we have the static approach.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: which is concerned with measurable outcomes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the other hand, there is the dynamic approach, in which livability is viewed as the hidden driving force behind that which is measurable.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: By framing livability as comprised of three components, indicators, percepts and needs-desires, we can show that the location of fit determines which is which.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Either it is a weighted function between percepts and our preferences,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: co-evaluation, or livability is a weighted function between indicators and percepts, which are biased towards our preferences.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Finally, these two approaches might be complementary, and this might be useful for modeling purposes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There are many different transport models.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: When it comes to those used for urban planning, these can be distinguished into micro and micro simulations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The micro scale simulates individual vehicles and their interactions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Meanwhile, the micro scale applies constraint optimization over a network.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Preferences constrain this optimization.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Here I will focus on micro models, which combine transport and land use patterns.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Fundamentally, we rely on seeing the transport system as a market.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: travelers generate demand, while the network provides supply.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The four-step model forms the backbone of Microscopic Transport Modeling, and I will go over each step.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: First is trip generation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This step determines how many trips start and end in each zone.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It is about determining the row and column sums.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: See also the top right figure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For trip production, we look at residential zones and use socio-demographic factors like household size, car ownership and income levels.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For trip attraction, we look at the number of jobs, shops or school capacity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Trip distribution iteratively balances row and column sums to fill the origin-destination matrix.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Balancing is done using a gravity model, where the number of trips increases
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: with their mass, but decreases with the travel resistance.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: With the full origin-destination matrix, we can split these flows per travel mode used.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The utility of each mode can be weighed against our order in the choice set.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Logit models can be estimated for different segments of the population.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That is the figure in the equation in the bottom right.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Finally, we assign trips to links in the network.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: According to Wardrop's first principle, travelers select routes to minimize the travel time, leading to an equilibrium where no user can reduce the travel time by changing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The entire workflow is iterative because assignment affects travel resistances due to congestion.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Not shown here is the modeling of land use, which affects zonal data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Next, I will outline three conceptual building blocks, which will be combined in the synthesis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As we just saw, modeling transport networks requires a representation, for example, the travel time per link.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Additionally, we would like to approximate human perception, for example, by using images or sounds.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The field of urban representation learning attempts to automatically capture the content and structure of cities.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Luckily, there is a strong inductive prior from Joker3.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Similar things are closer together.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As such, major design choices revolve around which measures of distance to include.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Examples are Euclidean distance, travel volumes or accessibility.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Generally, an application of urban representation learning relies on three choices.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: First is the need to discretize the urban region into spatial units.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Each acts as a class.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The figures on the right use hexagons.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Secondly is the type of data used.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Where traditional transport models only use tabular data, we can now also use street view images and text.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Last but not least is the way in which parameters are structured and learned.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Graph neural networks are widely used as they naturally represent the transport network.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Additionally, the loss function can be used to steer training.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Accessibility is a major field of study in transport planning that connects well with active inference concepts.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In urban representation learning, we aim to capture spatial similarity in embeddings.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Accessibility provides a theoretical foundation for which similarities to capture.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Intuitively, accessibility is akin to landscapes of affordances, which are shared by everybody living in an urban region.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Location-based accessibility is derived from constrained maximum entropy and can be configured to equal utility-based accessibility.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The calculation is straightforward.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For each zone, we sum the product of destination attractiveness and the deterrence function based on generalized travel cost.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The deterrence function captures how travel cost relates to similarity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As shown in the maps, accessibility patterns differ significantly between bike and car networks.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Hierarchy is a well-established element of transport networks.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Think of how local streets feed into arterials and highways, each operating at different speeds and distances.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Where local streets facilitate access, main roads enable throughput.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: To capture this hierarchy in urban representations, we start by defining the study area, creating columns of coarse hexagons and then mapping them to define our resolutions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I have used a U-Net to capture both bottom-up and top-down information.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Each block in this net is a graph convolutional neural network.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: A pre-computed accessibility graph sparsely connects centroids of hexagons, where the edges are the accessibility value.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Reconstruction loss ensures we capture input data
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: while consistency loss ensures columns of hexagons are integrated.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Combining context and building blocks, I will now go over the synthesis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We started by discussing digital twins and two approaches to livability, static and dynamic.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The dynamic approach frames livability as niche construction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: When it comes to policy, the problem boils down to the objective function used.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Could free energy act as an objective function for policy evaluation?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Unlike utility, free energy cannot be summed across decision makers.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Perception itself is subjective.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Meanwhile, with utility, we all live in the same fully observed world.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If urban regions engage in niche construction,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Perhaps we can create digital twins that embody the niche construction process.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Autonomy then becomes about influencing an existing process rather than creating something from scratch.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There are three potential approaches.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Agent-based models on a hex grid simulating individual travelers.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Simulating each hexagon as a cell with the expectation of emergent behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: or use a renormalizing generative model with a fixed hierarchy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The third option is the most promising, as it requires a single model rather than the combination of many smaller ones.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In line with this third approach, I want to consider a fixed hierarchy, and renormalizing generative models are perfectly suited to this purpose.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The idea is that these might already be transport models, as they map origins to destinations using cost functions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Sticking with the notion of a market equilibrium, there is a demand and a supply side to the operation of renormalizing generative models.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Just like in a four-step transport model, the demand side determines the landscape of afforded embeddings.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And these embeddings capture the spatial similarity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The supply side aims to calculate the distribution of flows through the network.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It is just that here, the network is a hierarchical structure, not the physical transport network.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the demand side, the landscape of affordances or the landscape of afforded embeddings is perceived through the combination of top-down prior and bottom-up data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: From the top-down, we impose our cost function.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: on traversing the lateral accessibility graph.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Attributes on edges are valued against each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For example, travel time and the price of petrol.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We also impose our preferences in terms of the content we wish to see.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the content of the embeddings.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For example, the concentration of emissions in the air.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: From the bottom up, we receive information for this lateral accessibility graph, like the travel time at this moment, as well as the content of discrete spatial units.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this content is in the form of embeddings inferred from high-dimensional data using neural networks, so that this process can be automated.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the supply side, we have a landscape of affordances at each layer in the hierarchy, and we need to parse messages between them.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Supply is about narratives of attention, either about errors flowing up or predictions moving down.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: To move laterally, you have to go up and over.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In doing so, carve the transport system at its joints.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For example, when you need to do groceries,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: you probably do not zoom out to the causes layer.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Instead, you will find crip much more quickly and walk a few blocks.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Using active inference as a framework to understand decision making in urban regions is still speculative.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The standard workflow of ex-ante evaluation to study the benefits of a project might not be applicable anymore
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: as the digital twin goes out to construct its niche on its own.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The separation between technical calculations and political motivations in planning becomes blurred.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: How do we capture both travel choice and policy objectives in one model?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Accessibility is already a central topic, yet it has now gained additional consideration due to the reframing into landscapes of references.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: These affordances may not only be in terms of tabular data, but can be high dimensional, like images.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Accessibility heavily draws upon constrained maximum entropy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Bayesian mechanics treats this the same as free energy minimization.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It therefore seems worthwhile to reframe accessibility in this way too.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Active inference is useful not only for autonomous urban digital twins, but also for level 4 twins.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: To refresh, level 4 twins use physics-based models with the addition of an interpretive layer.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This additional layer contains an understanding of the sensitivities between models, which allows an urban planner to quickly converge on a set of designs rather than simulate thousands of alternatives.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Therefore, a practical starting point would be to take level 3 digital twins and upgrade them with an active inference module to explore the parameter space efficiently.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The apparent complementarity of static and dynamic approaches of livability suggests that we could use representations learned through valuation, so a supervised way of learning urban representations,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: to then use them in learning the structure of an active inference model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In sum, it is fair to say that autonomous urban digital twins still need a lot of work.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Regardless, considering free energy as an alternative to utility is a valuable exercise in understanding decision making in urban regions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Lastly, I would like to thank the team of symposium organizers for their time and effort.
